author: pipermerriam
content: It should be possible to write the client in such a way that the bootnodes somewhat ignore the *extra* protocol messages, so the bootnodes in theory can be long lived and semi stable.  The other nodes in the network can come-and-go, but it would allow us to test in a public testnetwork

author: pipermerriam
content: <@!694014391288332358> just realized that OFFER/ACCEPT/STORE doesn't fit cleanly into the discv5 request/response paradigm.  I think this is ok, but probably worth pointing out because this would be yet another place where we would be going against the *base* protocol's un-enforceable rule that all requests have a corresponding response messages.

author: pipermerriam
content: I think the right way forward is to submit a patch to the base protocol definition to loosen this from a MUST to a SHOULD with some context.

author: jacobkaufmann
content: Thatâ€™s a good callout. Off the top of my head I guess the alternative is to use some form of ack message (eg STORED)?

author: pipermerriam
content: The ACK simply to comply with the request/response seems un-necessary so I'd say the default course of action would be to simply have STORE exist without a response message and to acknowledge the diversion from the stated rules of the base protocol in the spec.

author: pipermerriam
content: The uTP messages are likely to do the same thing (all TALKREQ, no TALKRESP) so unless we're going to comply across the board, I don't think we need to start inserting response message types where they aren't strictly needed.

author: jacobkaufmann
content: That makes sense. Just wanted to make sure it was considered and better understand the reasoning. Iâ€™ll make sure I acknowledge this in the history spec this before raising the PR
